item.title: 1st June 2025 - Balsam Bash
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Our June event was a balsam bash. Around 15 of us cleared invasive Himalayan balsam from the area around the Milking Bridge to make space for native species and prevent flooding.

item.title: 6th September 2025 - Moth Breakfast
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded:
Andrew Cockcroft of Halifax Scientific Society came to look at the moth population of the clough with us.

It's called a moth breakfast because he left a light box overnight and then came along in the morning and see which moths we had.

Unfortunately, there were only a few moths in the box in the morning, so Andrew will return in the spring. We still met on the park, and went on a walk around the clough, led by Robin.

UK Moth Identification and Facts: 12 common species for beginners (Woodland Trust website)

item.title: 5th October 2025 - Rhododen-gone!
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Meeting in Eaves Playground at 10am, we will be identifying and removing invasive species of rhododendron from the Clough.

item.title: 4th May 2025 - Woodland Management
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Our first woodland management event took place on the 4th May 2025. A group of 10 volunteers cleared beech saplings from a field just beyond the end of Eaves Avenue.

item.title: 6th July 2025 - Balsam Bash
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: A team of seven did some Himalayan Balsam clearance by the milking bridge on Sunday 6th July. As for previous events, we met on the playground at 10.00am and finished at 12.00 noon. It was a bit rainy and wet, but the results were spectacular!

item.title: 3rd August 2025 - Balsam Bash
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Our last two events on July 6th and June 1st were also Balsam bashes - there is a large amount of Himalayan Balsam in Colden Clough, and despite repeated attempts to stem its spread throughout the valley it continues to thrive.

item.title: 7th December 2025 - Beech party
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Our event on the 7th December will be a woodland management event - clearing beech saplings from the wood. As for previous events, we will meet on the playground at 10 am and finish by 12 noon. Feel free to leave early if you need to.

item.title: 21st February 2026 - Small Hedge planting
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded:
For our first mid-month event of 2026 we hope to be planting approximately 10 metres of hedgerow from the corner of the Eaves playground down the road to where the wall starts. This will be to increase biodiversity, reduce the footprint of invasivae species (Himalayan Balsam) and continue the hawthorn hedge from the park.

We are also planning to lay the existing hawthorn hedge in order to rejuvenate it and create a more effective barrier to the steep sloping land leading to the emergence of Colden Water from the tunnel under the playground. This will also create a vital wildlife corridor with food and shelter for birds, mammals, and insects, connecting fragmented habitats and supporting biodiversity, while also acting as a windbreak and helping carbon capture.

item.title: 1st February 2026 - Woodland Management
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Meeting on Eaves playground at 10am, we continued the beech removal from penny fields that was started last year. We felled three of the larger trees, using a rope to guide them down safely.

item.title: 2nd November 2025 - Rhododen-gone!
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Meeting in Eaves Playground at 10am, a team of eight cut down at least four large rhododendron from the Clough, near to the strip of land cleared for the power cables from Heptonstall. This was so much fun in October that we decided to do it again!

item.title: 4th January 2026 - Rhododen-gone!
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Meeting in Eaves Playground at 10am, a team of eight cut down some large and small rhododendron from the Clough, near to Hell Hole rocks. This was so much fun in October, November and December that we decided to do it again!

item.title: 7th December 2025 - Rhododen-gone!
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded: Meeting in Eaves Playground at 10am, a team of seven cut down some large and small rhododendron from the Clough, near to Hell Hole rocks. This was so much fun in October and November that we decided to do it again!

item.title: 14th February 2026 - Rhododen-gone!
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded:
This is the first of our mid-month work days. We will be meeting on the third Saturday of each month in addition to the first Sunday from March 2026 onwards.

Meeting in Eaves Playground at 10am, we will be clearing some large and small rhododendron from the Clough, near to Hell Hole rocks. This was so much fun in October, November and December that we decided to do it again!

item.title: 1st March 2026 - Moss breakfast
item.dc:creator: friendscoldenclough
item.content:encoded:
Join us on a gentle walk with local ecologist and bryologist Johnny Turner to explore the incredible diversity of mosses and liverworts of this special place.

Johnny has been studying the bryophytes of the Clough for many years and recorded nearly 200 species here!

Well be exploring a variety of habitats and discussing the importance of these tiny (and some not so tiny) plants and what they can tell us about environmental conditions.

We will start at 10am at Eaves Playground and walk up to Jack Bridge up the main track on the Colden side with the occasional detour, so please wear sturdy footwear and clothing suitable for the weather.

No previous knowledge of bryophytes required. Some 10x lenses will be available for use, but please bring one if you have one.

A voluntary donation at the end of the walk would be welcomed!
